column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=3. HDR Document Image Generation
#Text=3.1. Document Image Registration

#Text=The image registration problem has been intensively studied in remote sensing images , medical images , and camera images and very rarely , research can be found for document image registration .
#Text=The most popular registration in the context of exposure bracketing is from , where a translational geometric model was employed to account for the geometric disparity between two images .
#Text=However , we found that the translational model is not suitable for general camera document images .
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=shows two pseudo color image patches that are composed of two LDR images that are already illustrated in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=.
#Text=The green band and blue band come from the corresponding bands in the well-exposed image while the red band is from the corresponding band in the over-exposed image .
#Text=If there are no geometric disparities between these two images , the foreground ( textual part ) of the image should overlap .
#Text=In
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=, we can clearly see that geometric difference exists as the foreground texts do not overlap .
#Text=On top of it , we can clearly see that the global translational model cannot account for the geometric disparity between these two images .
#Text=For example ,
#Text=Figure 4

#Text=a is the left central image patch and we can see that the geometric difference between the well-exposed image and over-exposed image in this region is around 10 pixels ( half the size of the lowercase letter “ a ” ) in the vertical direction .
#Text=However , in
#Text=Figure 4

#Text=b , the right central image patch , we can see that the geometric difference between the well-exposed image and over-exposed image in this region is around 20 pixels ( the size of the lowercase letter “ a ” ) in the vertical direction .
#Text=This is obvious evidence that the geometric disparity between LDR images cannot be translational and that it must follow a more complicated geometric model .

#Text=Among all the geometric models , such as the affine model , translational model , rotation model , and so on , we ended up selecting the planar homograph model to represent the geometric disparity between LDR images .

#Text=Under this model , points in two different images can be mapped as : ( 1 ) where points are represented by homogeneous coordinates and so point ( x , y , z ) is the same as ( x / z , y / z ) in the inhomogeneous coordinate .

#Text=We selected this model because during the bracketing stage , hand-shake is inevitably introduced , leading to different imaging angles for the same document object , and the planar homograph model is suitable for the situation where the imaging object is put on a planar surface and is captured from different view-angles .
#Text=When the planar homograph model is selected , we have to estimate this model ’s eight parameters .
#Text=Basically , there are two methods .
#Text=The first method is called the area-based method .
#Text=Using this method to estimate the planar homograph model involves two steps :
#Text=in the first step , a moving window is defined in the reference image and the image patch within the window is regarded as the template .
#Text=We used the template to search for a corresponding image patch in the sensed image ( an image that was registered ) .
#Text=The centers of matched image templates are used as control points ( CPs ) .
#Text=There are many ways of finding a matching template , and one of the most popular criteria is cross correlation .
#Text=When multiple CPs are generated , we then use these CPs to estimate the planar homograph model .
#Text=Area-based methods , however , are not employed due to two reasons : ( 1 )
#Text=the first reason is that this method is computationally heavy as it performs cross correlation on multiple image patches and ( 2 )
#Text=the second reason is that image patches under different exposure levels may display extremely different characteristics , which may fail cross the correlation method .
#Text=The second method to estimate the planar homograph transformation is called the feature-based method .
#Text=Two critical steps in feature-based methods are feature extraction and feature matching .

#Text=We expect that the extracted features will be consistent regardless of exposure levels and among all the feature extraction methods , we selected the Scale-invariant Feature Transform ( SIFT ) method because it improves detection stability in situations of illumination changes .
#Text=In the meantime , it achieves almost real-time performance and the features that are detected are highly distinctive .

#Text=SIFT does not only define the position of detected points , but also provides a description of the region around the feature point by means of a descriptor , which is then used to match SIFT feature points .
#Text=Therefore , we have used the SIFT method to find CP pairs .
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=shows the extracted matched SIFT features for two LDR images .
